Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cooperation, grooming exchange, and supply and demand among free-ranging primates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One defining characteristic of humans is their unusually cooperative nature, which is unparalleled among animals. An important goal for anthropology is to understand the nature and evolution of this "altruistic" behavior. This doctoral dissertation project will investigate cooperative exchanges among free-ranging rhesus macaques in order to test predictions from several competing evolutionary hypotheses about altruism. Studying cooperative exchanges among rhesus macaques will provide a comparative model for understanding the behavioral evolution of humans and our ancestors. The broader impacts of this project include the support of science education and outreach, through valuable field experience for research assistants, data analysis experience for undergraduates, and presentation of research results in various public formats, including local zoos and conferences.

This study will observe grooming interactions among 50 adult female rhesus macaques from three social groups at Cayo Santiago, Puerto Rico, using focal animal sampling methodology, for eleven months (spanning both mating and birth seasons). Specifically, the project will examine how well reciprocal grooming exchanges resemble those predicted by several competing theoretical hypotheses (kin selection, reciprocal altruism, biological markets theory, and social bond investment), in one comprehensive and integrated analysis, via AIC model ranking. These exchanges will be examined across multiple time scales and across groups of variable sizes. Additionally, there will be a more detailed investigation of biological markets theory. By focusing on exchanges of grooming for mates or infant handling, this study will test a key prediction that such exchanges conform to supply and demand relationships. The extent to which apparent supply and demand relationships may be artifacts of, or mediated by, stress responses will be examined, with stress measured both behaviorally and via fecal glucocorticoid metabolite assays.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scope and willingness of modern humans to behave altruistically, that is to help others at a cost to themselves, demands explanation, as the existence of any costly behavior seemingly defies natural selection. Therefore, one important goal for anthropology is understanding the nature and evolution of altruism. Like humans, rhesus macaques (Macaca mulatta) rely on cooperation to navigate their social world. This project investigated cooperative exchanges among free-ranging Cayo Santiago rhesus macaques, specifically by examining grooming for infant handling exchanges and time matching behavior when grooming was reciprocally exchanged for itself. Time matching is an important diagnostic tool for measuring reciprocation, and it occurs when there is a positive relationship between grooming times invested by each partner. Given their close relatedness to humans, studying cooperative exchanges among rhesus will help researchers reconstruct earlier stages of human behavioral evolution.

Data were collected on Cayo Santiago over a 15 month period, investigating three questions: 1) whether grooming for infant handling exchanges conform to supply and demand principles, 2) whether maternal stress levels mediate the appearance of supply and demand in these exchanges, and 3) whether the methodology chosen by researchers influences interpretations about time matching. Supply and demand relationships have inconsistently been found to operate in grooming for infant handling exchanges in other primate species, such that grooming durations provided by handlers to mothers decrease as the availability of infants in the group increases. It is unclear whether market conditions are solely responsible for this relationship, or whether maternal stress levels are also involved.  While increases in grooming when commodities become scarce may indicate market effects, they may also be byproducts of increased attention and/or harassment towards mothers of scarce infants. Grooming could serve as a benign signal of intent or even function to de-stress commodity holders. We hypothesized that stress may serve as a mechanism mediating the appearance of supply and demand. While we did find evidence for supply and demand operating in the grooming for infant handling exchanges among rhesus macaques, we found no evidence that stress impacts this relationship. We measured stress both behaviorally and physiologically, and found no relationship between maternal stress levels and infant availability. Finding evidence for supply and demand in the absence of stress effects is an important finding, as it highlights a major similarity between primate and human market exchanges, which do not characteristically involve mediation by stress.

Our investigations of reciprocal grooming exchanges provide the first evidence for short-term time matching in rhesus macaques. As with the appearance of supply and demand, conclusions about time matching also vary across species. Generally, researchers focus on the duration of pauses between grooming episodes that involve a switch in partner roles and choose a cut-off point to distinguish short from longer term reciprocation. Problematically, researchers have made inconsistent choices about these cut-offs. Such inconsistencies are potentially concerning, as it is unclear whether resulting inconsistent conclusions about short-term time matching are attributable to species and/or ecological differences, or are due partly to methodological inconsistency. We investigated whether various criteria for distinguishing short from long-term reciprocation influence conclusions about short-term time matching, by comparing several commonly used cut-offs to ones generated by the currently preferred approach of survival analysis. While most cut-offs yielded similar degrees of time matching as the one derived from survival analysis, very short ones significantly underestimated both the degree of time matching and the influence of rank distance on time matching. Our results highlight the ways in which methodological inconsistency can influence interpretations of behavior across studies. This is important not only for investigations of time matching, but also more generally.

In addition to helping train four research assistants on data collection techniques, providing them with necessary skills for graduate school, the broader impacts of this research include outreach provided to local communities in Puerto Rico in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria. Hurricane Maria was one of the worst natural disasters to hit the US, striking Puerto Rico in the middle of data collection for this project. The impact of Hurricane Maria on the field station, as well as the Punta Santiago community where researchers reside, was catastrophic. My field team was heavily involved with volunteer efforts to help restore the field site, and was actively engaged in volunteer efforts in the local community, including painting, debris removal, scraping, and shipment of supplies. In addition to volunteering at the field site and in the Punta Santiago community, we also helped organize a science book drive for the neighboring community of Rio Grande. Prior to the hurricane, there was a small library in the visitor center at the base of the El Yunque rainforest. Through our efforts, we were able to donate over 500 science books to the library; these books serve as the basis for the only public library on Puerto Rico’s east coast.
